1.content:
It is very dark. The only lighting comes from sparsely mounted globes that glow with a soft white luminescence and from the occasional bluish-white shower of sparks or lightning-like flash overhead. The constant echo of whirring and grinding noises are interrupted only by the all-too-frequent blood curdling scream. The fetid smell of sweat, decay, and something unnamable hangs heavily in your nostrils. There must some a way out of this waking nightmare.

But first, who are you?
1.title: Who are you?

choices: You are visited by a young halfling rogue named Jade
You are visited by a a strange old gnome calling himself Whitebeard
You pull at your shakles until you hands are magled and ripped free
You break the handles off the mill post and climb to the metal grate overhead
11.content:
You are a hulking minotaur with more fur covered muscle than a bison. Your deadly axe and ogre’s strength have lead to a distinguished and profitable career as a mercenary, at least until your last job...

You were escorting a dwarven cartography team deep into a system of natural caverns when you got ambushed by a group of mindflayers. You decapitated one of the hideous squid-headed men with your first swing, but your mind and body reeled and then shut down from the assault of their mind blasts. You vaguely remember a period of time after that as one of their thrall, like a nightmare of being a puppet to some insane overlord. When you woke, you found yourself chained to a mill wheel. You are now fed based on how much you turn the wheel.

Your first thought was escape, but that was thwarted both by your weakness from near starvation and by the unbreakable adamantine chains that keep you fastened to the 6’ thick stone pillar of the mill wheel. If you push the handle of the wheel with all your might and walk it around the circle, you can cause the mill to rotate, earning you a few scraps of food for several hours of constant turning.

Your second thought was the horrific realization that they had sawed your horns down to flat stubs, in effect, sawing off your pride and honor. Your burning rage against the mindflayers for this insult will remain until death, either yours or theirs.

In the past week, you have regained your strength from the meager food and constant exercise by turning the wheel for about 16 hours a day. Now, as you turn the mill wheel, you remain coldly alert to every detail around you, waiting for an opportunity to escape your laborious prison and punish your captors.
11.title: Torune, the Minotaur Mercenary

113.content:
You have your strength back, but you have run out of patience waiting for opportunity, so it's time to visit some old friends of yours... Pain and sacrifice.

You grab the right shackle with your left hand and pull with all your considerable might. Slowly, and yes, quite painfully, your right hand begins to squeeze into the adamantine shackle. Your dark brown fur-covered hand turns crimson red as the skin rips and cotes it with blood. The bones in your hand and thumb begin to crunch and snap as you grit your teeth and continue to pull. Finally, your bloody mangled hand pulls free of the shackle.

You use the intense pain and adrenaline to keep going. Bracing your hoof on the rim of the left shackle, you do the same damage to your other hand until at last; you are free of the bonds. Your hands are now useless and your horns are gone, but you can still kick, bite, and charge at anything unfortunate to get in your way. You are pissed, and that's exactly what you need to get out of this place.

You howl with rage and charge at the door on the far wall, battering with your massive shoulder and splitting it with a loud crack. You find yourself at the base of a spiral staircase, so you quickly ascend, taking the steps 3 at a time, until you reach a passage at the top. The dimly lit passage goes to your left and to your right.
113.title: Pain shmain

choices: You go down the side passage, where the goblin thralls were headed
You continue down the passage, where the goblin thralls came from
You double back, following your own blood trail back to the first passage choice
1131.content:
You don't take long to decide, since you're still busy losing blood from your shredded hands. The foul scent of mindflayers is stronger to the left, so you go left. Your darkvision allows you to see clearly in what would otherwise be a barely lit long straight corridor topped by an iron grate a few feet above your eight foot stature.

After about fifty feet, the passage turns sharply to the right. As soon as you round the corner, you see your first obstacle. Two goblins are dragging a third goblin, which is either dead or unconscious, from the other end of the passage. They were about to turn the corner down a side passage when they spot you spotting them. They drop the body of the third goblin and draw their swords. You notice a certain drooling slack-jawed stiff gate to them as they turn to face you. Good, they are thralls. They may not be the mindflayers you crave to pound on, but at least the mindflayers controlling them will get the idea.

By the time they finish freeing the blades from their scabbards, you have already closed the twenty foot distance between you and hit them both like a runaway horse, trampling them as you slide and stomp your great hooves into the rock floor and bloody crunching goblins, trying to slow yourself down and turn around. One goblin now looks worse then the motionless goblin they were carrying. The other is badly injured, but staggers upward and thrusts his little shortsword into your lower abdomen. You grab the blade with your already cut and broken hand and yank it from your gut and his hand, tossing it aside. The new wound adds to the pain which adds to the force of your headbutt as you drop it down on the goblin like a falling bolder. You’re not sure if the crunching sound is his skull, neck, or both, but there is no question that he is dead as you straighten back up.

You look back at the bodies and the trail of blood and realize that the trail is yours; marking the entire path you have taken from the mill wheel to your current spot. The slit in your stomach is pouring blood freely and will leave a much thicker trail. You start to feel dizzy from the blood loss, but then you shake it off and decide you don't have time for that.
1131.title: Goblin crossing

11311.content:
You thought that you were as pissed off as you could possibly get, but you were wrong.

The short passage ends in a door which you plow into like a wounded rhino. I cracks and swings open, allowing you to stagger through the threshold, dragging your feet.

The part that pisses you off more than before is the realization that the brightness and dragging of your feet are warnings that you are going to pass out. You growl with rage, still trying to shake it off, when you hear a woman scream nearby. You search to room for its source, but only see the rock floor coming rapidly up to meet you...
11311.title: I got no time to bleed

choices: You go down the passage where the goblins came from
You go down the passage marked by your dried blood
113111.content:
You hear a distant voice and color is returning to your surroundings. The voice is next to your and sounds urgent.

“Come on! Wake up! We need to go!”

You see the concerned face of a human woman over you, as she tries unsuccessfully to shake your massive shoulder.

“Can you hear me? I killed one!” The woman is almost sobbing. “The others could be here any second!”

You force yourself to sit up. Your head is pounding and you feel groggy. Your hands and stomach are tightly wrapped in bandages. The smell of mindflayer hangs in your nostrils. You turn toward the source and see one of your captors lying dead on the floor in a puddle of black blood, a shortsword, the same goblin’s shortsword that stabbed you, buried nearly hilt-deep into its tentacled mouth. The site of the dead mindflayer finally stirs you into action. You heave yourself up to your hooves and stagger after the woman, who is already leaving the room.

You catch up to her as she gingerly pulls a shortsword out from under the goblin that you trampled to death. You still smell mindflayers down the passage that the goblins had come from.
113111.title: We gotta go!

choices: You work on the remaining grate so you can climb up into the area above
You climb up and look around through the opening you've made so far
You wait for the goblin to come through the door and show him your new toy
114.content:
You're done pushing this stupid wheel like some kind of farmer's ox! The insult fills you with a sudden overwhelming bout of rage and you roar with fury, grabbing the handle and shaking it up and down, until the iron-reinforced log-sized handle that runs through a hole in the six foot thick stone column cracks and splinters, the iron reinforcements bending and snapping under the tremendous pressure.

The handle breaks free and you realize you are now holding a decent battering ram. You can't quite reach the door and there is still no way for you to break the adamantine chain or shackles, but maybe if you could climb to the top of the center post...

You heft the huge broken handle until it is vertical and then you thrust it upward into the iron grate, about five feet over your head. It clangs and rattles. You hit it again, and again, and again. Finally, on about the tenth pissed-off blow, a five foot section of the iron grate buckles and pops to the side, leaving an opening in the ceiling above.

Exhausted, you let the log-sized handle drop tot he ground with a thud and you catch your breath.

Now what?

The chain is above the cross handles to your left and right, but it's still draped under the handle opposite the one you broke. You might be able to break or pull out the opposite handle and then...

You could try to bash through the rest of the ceiling grates so that you could use the chain as leverage and climb the center column into the area above you; or you could just climb up and see if there is anything up there work breaking the rest of the grates for; or you could just wait for the goblin that brings your food - maybe he has the key to your shackles...
114.title: I'm no farmer's ox!

1141.content:
You gather your strength and your 'battering ram' and start pounding on the next section of grate. This one takes a bit longer, but you finally bust it open, take a short break, and then begin pounding on the next.

You smell a familiar smell and hear a noise outside the door. The smell is unmistakably mindflayer, but there is another smell. Is that, troll?

Yep, it's troll. The door flies open and there is a large troll. Over his shoulder, you see a mindflayer.

You can take the troll, as long as that cowardly mindflayer stays out of your head. The troll is already bounding toward you from the doorway and you square off, getting ready to batter his head with the huge handle. You thrust and, in spite of the troll trying to parry it, the log connects with his head, making a sick snapping sound.

The troll staggers from your blow, and then you stagger from a blinding pain that feels like an explosion went off inside your own head. Damn squid! You knew he wasn't going to wait for his turn. The ground rushes up to meet you and you succumb to the darkness...
1141.title: Wait your turn!

1143.content:
You grab the battering ram and ready yourself, picturing the look on the goblin's face when he comes through the door and you chuck it at his head. You only hope you can still reach him and that he has a key...

You smell a familiar smell and hear a noise outside the door. The smell is not goblin though, it is mindflayer, and there is another smell...

Is that, troll?

Yep, it's troll. The door flies open and there is a large troll. Over his shoulder, you see a mindflayer.

You can take on a troll, but you know that mindflayer isn't going to wait his turn. You heave the log-sized handle at the mindflayer's head, but the troll catches it before it hits your target and charges you with it. You square off; preparing to fight the troll when you are hit by a blinding pain that feels like an explosion went off inside your mind. Damn squid! You knew he wasn't going to wait for his turn.

The last thing you see as the ground comes up to meet you is the troll bringing the battering ram down on your head.

You are dead. Feel free to go back and try another path, since thankfully, this is only a story.
1143.title: Come and get it!

choices: You create a distraction and then leap onto the illithid's floating disk
You remove your leather pants and use them to slide down a cable
You slide down a cable when it goes dark, hoping it won't light up soon
12.content:
You are a young elf woman. Your striking beauty is second only to your deadly accuracy with a bow. You have the eyes of a hawk, the reflexes of a cat, and the archery skills of a master sniper. Unfortunately, that does you little good in your present state as a slave to the Illithid. You have no memory of your capture or of how long you have been a slave in this dark, underground Illithid city. You only have distant memories of your childhood in the beautiful forest city of Lundell and of your unmatched prowess as an archer.

You miss the sunlight and the trees and the elves of your homeland and, most of all, you miss the feel of a bowstring that could send arrows into the milky-white eyes of your foul smelling captors. But you don’t have a bow or arrows or even a safe place to rest. You are trapped atop the rafters and cables suspended high above the dark Illithid city, near the ceiling of a mountain-sized cavern, always one false step away from plunging to your death.

You work for scraps of food, cleaning and repairing the structure and cables. Your orders, food, and water are carried to you by a drider (a drow elf abomination with the upper body of a dark elf and the lower body of a huge spider). The cables that hang downward into the dark city would be a means of escape if they weren’t almost constantly glowing and crackling with lighting. One of your earliest memories after your capture is watching another slave accidently touch a glowing cable and get instantly fried to a crisp.

Occasionally, an Illithid ascends to your elevation riding some sort of floating disk, and stares at you with its cold, solid white eyes. Every time this happens, the drider gives you several new tasks and becomes extra violent if you show any hesitation in carrying them out. Now, with the other slave dead, your only companions are the occasional hideous illithid, bad-tempered drider, and the constant hissing, whirring, grinding, clanking noise rising from the dark depths below you, like some giant nightmarish machine. You keep one constant eye on your footing and the other out for some opportunity to escape this dark hell with your life.
12.title: Arial, the Elven Archer

122.content:
You never were the modest type, and its not like there's enough light in this abyss for anyone to get a good look at you anyway, so you quickly undo and strip off your leather breeches and watch the nearest cable as it sputters and crackles with energy. The floating illithid and the drider have both been absent for a while, so now is as good a time as any.

You wait for the cable to go black and, hoping against hope that this little blackout will be one of the longer ones, you toss a pant leg over the cable and drop, sliding down the steeply drooping cable into the darkness while holding onto the cuffs of your leather breeches for dear life...

The first thing that hits you is the cold air rushing past your bare legs.

The next thing that hits you is panic as the cable lights up again after only a couple seconds. A second after that, your breeches catch fire, and a few seconds after that, just as the slope of the cable was starting to shallow and slow your decent, your burning breeches tear and you are plummeting into the darkness...
122.title: Hangin in the breeze

choices: Might as well try this passage before the illithid find you up here.
Might want to keep going and see what else you can find from this upper level.
1221.content:
Thankfully, you land much sooner than expected, painfully but safely slamming into a metal grate! You stand shakily and drop your useless smoldering pant legs. At least you’re wearing undergarments. As you peer around your dimly-lit surroundings, you hear a voice from directly beneath you.

“Hey!” The voice is a loud whisper.

“Hey… are you okay?” You ask the voice, looking down through the grate at your feet and seeing what looks like either a young child or a halfling woman trapped in a small cell.

"I'd be better if you could pull on that metal bar next to you that keeps my cage locked!"

You quickly bend down and feel a metal bar and cable near the spot where you landed. You feel one section that is attached to a large spring and try pulling hard. It starts move a little, and just when you think to ask if you’re pulling the right bar, you hear a clank and see that the cell door has popped open.

“Yes!” the voice squeals. You look around nervously, wondering if the noise you made from your landing and the squeal of joy from what you have determined must be a female halfling are going to alert the illithid. “Thank you!” the voice whispers in a much quieter tone.

"Anytime!" You whisper back, then looking around for some way down to her, you add "I don't see a way through this grate, so I'm going to keep going. My name is Areal, by the way. Maybe will meet up later. If not, good luck."

"I'm Jade.” She replies, “I'll keep an eye out for you on my way out of this hell. Thanks again."

You decide that you have pressed your luck quite enough, so you wave down at the halfling and trot briskly, but silently across the metal grate. Coming to a ledge, you turn and grab onto the grate, dangling and feeling for a foothold. Your feet find crossbars and you climb down about ten feet and feel another metal grate floor. You walk across it a little ways and see a light below you. It looks like there is an access hatch here, with a latch on your “floor” side that opens into a passage below. You could open it and drop down into the passage, or you could go further across what looks to be the roof over a network of other passages.
1221.title: A little good deed

12212.content:
You pad silently into the darkness, across the cold metal grate, leaving the dimly lit floor hatch behind. You are not too anxious to be trapped again, and the passage below that hatch looked too confining. At least up here, you have room to run...

The hair stands up on the back of your neck. Something is watching you. You freeze in the darkness, looking around and straining your ears. Your keen elven senses can see in the dimmest light and hear a twig snap from a mile away, but you see nothing and hear only the same monotonous grinding, hissing, and crackling cacophony that you have been trying to ignore for days.

You look up. There is movement there. A round shadow growing directly above you, blacker than the surrounding blackness.

You run.
12212.title: Out in the open

122121.content:
You are sprinting across the metal grate, back toward the lit hatch. Maybe if you can get through it...

You glance over your shoulder as your feet thunder across the rattling grate and then you see it. An illithid standing on a floating disk is rapidly descending from behind you and will close the distance in seconds. If only you had your bow!

You turn and dive painfully for the hatch, wrestling the latch open and heaving the metal trap door open...

You vision flashes bright white as what feels like a tree falling on your head hits your brain with a snap. The last thought as you slip into unconsciousness is déjà vu. This is the second time an illithid has hit you with its mind blast...
122121.title: Run!

1221211.content:
You feel like your waking up from a deep sleep and you are moving. Your head is pounding as you open your eyes and, through blurred vision, you see that you are being drug by your hair across a stone floor. You struggle to move your legs and twist to see what has a hold of you. The illithid gives you a hard shake, causing you to loose your footing before you completely gain it, and drags you a few more feet before pinning your head roughly down on a stone pedestal that is covered with dried blood.

You scream and thrash, but the illithid is strong and unmoved by your desperate flailing. The room you're in looks familiar and you realize that the empty cell that you see out of the corner of you eye was the same cell that you released the halfling from earlier. What was her name?

"Jade! Help me!" You scream out at the top of your lungs, but she is either long gone or not close enough to stop the illithid, as the tentacles hanging from its face latch onto your head. You feel a blinding pain as tiny razor-sharp spines along the tentacles puncture your scalp and skull, then crack it open and peel it back, exposing your brain to the drooling maw of the illithid...

You are dead. Feel free to go back and choose another path since, thankfully, this is only a story.
1221211.title: A quick snack

123.content:
You've been watching the cables, trying to see some sort of pattern to their momentary blackouts. Sometimes they go dark only for a second, and sometimes they go dark for several minutes. So far, you have seen no discernable pattern, but you're getting desperate.

The last task you were given was to scrape some rust and corrosion off of one of the cables where it connected to a cylinder that hung from the cavern ceiling. The cable was dark while you scraped at the corrosion, but the drider was standing next to you the entire time and jabbing at you with the tip of his razor sharp glaive and pushing you to hurry. Between the painful cuts from the drider and the stress of the thinking cable might light up again, since you didn't know for sure that they shut it down just for you, you were at the end of your rope. When you finally finished, the cable crackled with energy half a second after you backed away. The drider gave you one more painful jab for spite and crawled back into the darkness.

You've decided to gamble on the cables, thinking death can't be much worse that this torturous existence anyway. You sit staring a nearby crackling cable, watching it sputter. It goes dark a couple of times for only a second. When it goes dark again, you hope it might be due for a longer blackout and you make your move...
123.title: Jump!  Jump!  Jump!

1231.content:
You leap onto the dark cable, hook your ankles around it, and half pull hand-over-hand, half slide down the cable as fast as you can. All too soon you feel a bone-jarring jolt as it crackles back to life. Your hands and ankles are blown free, but you are falling and you can’t tell how far...

You realize after falling for several seconds, that you have fallen too far. You resign yourself to imminent death and wait for the impact…

It comes in an instant, but the pain is only a brief crack as your spine is broken before you succumb to the darkness.

You are dead. Feel free to go back and try another path, since thankfully, this is only a story.
1231.title: Playing chicken with the bug zapper

choices: You create enough crude explosive to blow some locks open
You create a device that protects you from mental assaults
You injure yourself, thinking the healer might help
13.content:
You don’t remember your own name or how you got into the bowels of the Illithid machine. In fact, you remember very little, but there are several things you have discovered over the last few days.

1. You are a gnome of advanced years and even more advanced intelligence. You go by the nickname Whitebeard, obviously due to your appearance.

2. You are a slave in an underground city of Illithid, or mind flayers, as they are commonly called.

3. You have a knack for engineering. You are tasked with maintenance and simple projects regarding electrified cables, capacitors, and the springs and gears of some giant powered clockwork mechanism. These tasks are simple, though, and your old mind churns with ideas of much greater complexity.

4. You have a knack for magic. Arcane words to half remembered spells drift though your mind. Occasionally, a complete spell comes clearly into focus, but after you caused one of the Illithid to burn to death, they stunned you with their psionic abilities and cut out your tongue. So now you cannot utter a single word, much less cast a spell.

5. The Illithid can read your mind. Every time you start to make progress on something they didn’t instruct you to do, they appear and scramble your poor brain. It’s not a complete scramble, as bits of your memory linger after each incident, but it is more than enough to cause you to guard your thoughts very carefully.

6. You have found a way to think about possibilities of escape by re-associating your thoughts with random silliness, which appears to confound your captors.

7. Using your new method of deceptive thinking, you have devised some possible secret projects that might aid in your escape…
a. You remember something about explosives, and you might have the materials to craft some.
b. You might be able to construct some sort of helmet that could give you protection from the illithid phychic powers.
c. You have a vague memory of a healer. If you can get to her, maybe she can surgically graft you a new tongue so that you could cast spells again.

Currently, you work on a blown capacitor while trying to decide which project to pursue first and abstractly applying your thoughts to a rather amusing limerick.
13.title: Whitebeard, the Gnome Engineer/Wizard

131.content:
The grey goo is stable as chowder,
the black stuff just stinks up the room.
But mixed with this powder,
it couldn’t be louder
‘cause fire will make it go boom!

While chuckling at your clever and spontaneous little rhyme, you’ve managed to mix up a batch of some horrible smelling goop which, if you have calculated correctly, should be quite unstable. In fact, you find yourself holding your breath and wincing at the close proximity of the jar to your personal space.

You whistle nervously as you cross the room and use your spoon to smear a small dab on the door to your room, near where you always hear it being unlatched from the other side. You then retreat to the other end of the room, setting the jar inside a metal box for safety, and pretend to concentrate on the inane project that you were last tasked with while you wait for the goblin that brings your less-than-delectable food every day around this time…
131.title: What rhymes with BOOM?

choices: You go to the right (because it seems less 'sinister')
You stay put and think of some better puns
1311.content:
Finally, you hear the brainless goblin thrall shuffle up to your door and fumble with the latch…

You focus on the dab of goop and snap your fingers, using the simple, wordless little cantrip that every wizard knows – to ‘light the candle’…

KABOOOOM!

The door explodes in a thundering crash of smoke and splinters. You are knocked off your feet and momentarily dazed by the surprisingly potent reaction. You stagger up and note with gleeful satisfaction that the goblin is charred and motionless on the floor just outside the now doorless frame. You rush over and retrieve the jar of goop, and then carefully but quickly, you exit the room with the dangerous jar held at arms length, not that arms length is anywhere far enough to save you or anyone else within a hundred feet if it goes off! The passage outside extends to your left and right. It is too smoke-filled and dimly lit to see where either direction leads.
1311.title: KABOOOOM!

13112.content:
You walk at a brisk but level pace to the right, down the dark corridor. You are quite hopeful after several twists and turns, that you are indeed approaching the surface, since the passage you are currently traversing slopes upward at about a 15% grade.

Oddly, though, this passage is riddled with holes. These holes pose a riddle that makes you feel very uneasy indeed, as you slow you pace and wonder if you should turn back.

The riddle is answered in an instant, however, as black slimy tentacles shoot out from the holes, wrapping around your torso and limbs from every direction.

You try to shout a warning - something like "That's not a good idea!" But without your tongue, what comes out is closer to "Aa'h o a oo iea!" Of course you realize that the source of the tentacles is unlikely to understand you your words whether they were clear or not. The jar of explosive goop is wrenched from your grasp and it falls to the ground, tumbling through the tentacles along the way. You close your eyes at it hits...

You may at least gain some satisfaction knowing that the collapsed corridor to the illithid dining room is going to cause them more than a small inconvenience.

You are dead. Feel free to go back and try another path, since thankfully, this is only a story.
13112.title: That's not a good idea!

132.content:
Bloody copper and iron... that's all the squidhead's use. You tug the dangling fur on your scarlet face while you rummage through the scrap pile.
Wait! What is this?... You pull at the end a short broken wooden shaft and find a beautiful engraved opal the size of your fist! They must have been busy to miss this little treasure.

A thought strikes you and suddenly the precious stone becomes a fleshy bone. Instead of the giant scintillating opal expertly mounted on the tip of a broken ash staff, you can almost clearly see, in your mind's eye, a salted turkey drumstick, with bits of yummy meat clinging to the bone.

That'll taste right nice that will... you think to yourself 'out loud' in a wild bid to throw your mind reading captors off the scent. Might as well have a snack before I get back to work...
132.title: Nice stone... I mean bone

1321.content:
Mmmm... turkey.. and not half rancid! You pretend to think cheerfully, pretending to chew and imagining vividly how it would taste and smell. Your stomach grumbles at the deception, having been fed only the worst gristly, pasty, obnoxiously rotten gruel that it has ever encountered since your captivity here.

You have pinned your hopes on the theory that the illithid only read your conscious thoughts, as you subconsciously work out the design in the back of your mind...

The copper circlet should fit snuggly enough on my head, providing connectivity to the opal, which has engravings that are not arcane, but definitely magical in nature. Probably divine and hopefully protective. Of course I have as much chance of protecting my head from acid or flames as I do psionic abilities, but there is something about this stone. Almost as if something inside it is telling me...

HOW SCRUMPTIOUS IT IS!

You realize that your thoughts have slipped and you scramble to complete the work. You hear footsteps outside the door and you abandon the obviously pointless ruse. You place the gemmed copper circlet on your head as the door flies open...
1321.title: That was a yummy stone... er... bone!

13211.content:
Much to your dismay, a rather large hideous troll steps through the open door. You can see the shadowy figure of an illithid behind it.

No! Not a troll! Your mind cries out in bewildered frustration as the troll lumbers into the workshop with a ravenous look on its face.

You were gambling on the theory that the opal would protect your mind from the illithid mind blasts, but now you feel a bit like an ‘hors duvre’ with legs - and short legs at that. You doubt very much that the opal will protect your body from being ripped open by strong sharp claws and teeth.

You scamper and dive beneath a table as the troll lunges for you. It is big and clumsy compared to a gnome, but you're getting too old for a game of tag, and if this thing manages to 'tag' you, the 'it' you'll be is something of a light snack. As you dash out from under the table, only an inch from the troll's grasp, you reach up and grab a beaker that was sitting on the table's edge.

Alas, the beaker is not full of acid as you intended, but of oil. You can hear the loud slapping of the troll's feet pounding the stone floor and you can feel its malodorous breath on the back of you neck. The troll's lethal proximity makes you jump and drop the oil beaker in the process, which shatters behind you. You are sprinting toward the doorway (and the illithid standing in it) as fast as your short legs will carry you. The odd slapping sound behind you and the fact that your haven't been nabbed by the troll causes your panicking mind to realize that the troll must have slipped and fell in the puddle of oil that you inadvertently left in your wake.

Ha! I'm not dead yet! You think to yourself, elated at the mishap of the slippery oil, but you quickly becoming more concerned at the illithid. The illithid has stepped through the doorway toward you and is wriggling its slimy tentacles, probably a gesture which denotes the activation of it mind blast...

You keep running right for the illithid, aware that the troll has recovered its footing and is once again closing the distance. You brace yourself for a painful loss of consciousness from the mind blast, but nothing happens...

Yes! The stone is working! You look over your shoulder just in time to see the troll coming down on you like an avalanche of muscle, claws, and teeth. You reach up and snap both fingers, attempting a wordless magical cantrip to 'light the pair of candles' while focusing on the trolls eyes. Two tiny sparks of flame hit their marks and the troll howls, shutting its momentarily blinded eyes. You dive between the enraged illithid's legs and leap to the side as the blind troll barrels accidentally into the illithid.

If you wait for them to recover, you'll be dead for sure, so you must decide immediately at a direction to run in the passage outside the workshop...
13211.title: Who invited the troll?

choices: Croton, Human Sorcerer and Student of Metamagic
14.content: Choose one of the six characters provided, or choose "Custom Character" to create your own. If choosing custom, please read the DM Only info (last link in the intro) and some of the provided character backgrounds to get an idea of what's expected.
14.title: Other Character Choices...

choices: There is an 'unauthorized visitor' at your door
You make a weapon, this time with more haste and less quality, and get ready
141.content:
You are a master dwarven craftsman. You once made armor and weapons for kings and siege devices for armies, but since your capture by mind flayers some weeks ago, all you have crafted is gears, screws, cables, and other parts for some infernal machine, the purpose of which, you have no idea.

It happened during an expedition in which you accompanied your cartographer brother Fafnir, both for his protection and for the possibility of discovering rare minerals to use in your craft. You, your brother, three other dwarves, and one very large hired minotaur wielding a steel great axe that was your finest work, stumbled onto a group of five mind flayers. The minotaur beheaded one of the squid-men and you put another down, crushing its ribs with a mighty blow from your obsidian warhammer. But the remaining three used their mental powers to incapacitate you and your team. The minotaur became a puppet for the mind flayers, helping them to herd the rest of you deeper, into this underground city. The malevolent mind flayers reduced your brother and his companions into drooling idiots and herded them off, probably to have their brains eaten like bowls of chowder in a mess hall. You, on the other hand, were put to work. You surmise that the squidies were able to read your mind and saw that you were a skilled artisan.

So here you are, locked up in a dismal workshop, listening to a constant mechanical clatter, occasionally interrupted by some pathetic screams. A few days into your work, you tried crafting a weapon. You were nearly finished with it when the foul mind-reading squidies caught you and gouged out your left eye with it. Now, with only one eye left, you craft only what they tell you to, getting your orders from the slobbering mindless goblin thrall that brings your food and water. You bide your time and mask your thoughts as best you can, trying to somehow figure out a means of escape without actually thinking about it.
141.title: Argos Blackhammer, the Dwarven Blacksmith

1412.content:
Looking around at what you have to work with, you quickly come up with three possibilities...

a. You could simply sharpen a long iron bar into a spear. It's certainly not your weapon of choice, but you could make it very sharp in less than a minute.

b. You could attach a sharp heavy twisted chunk of scrap iron to an iron bar, effectively making a decent mace. It would take twice as long as the spear, but you could wield it better.

c. You could put a length of chain between that same twisted chunk and iron bar, making a nasty flail. This would take you the longest, but if you were able to finish it, you could take a squiddie's head off with it!
1412.title: It don't have to look pretty

14121.content:
You decide speed is of the essence. Grabbing a long iron bar, you whistle nonchalantly and begin hammering the end into a flat pointed tip. You won’t be able to throw it effectively, but it should stab just fine. Just as long as you get the drop on it and there isn’t a group of them like the first time.

As you work, you pretend that you are crafting a tool to make fixing jammed gears easier, hoping that will fool the squiddies. Still, you can’t help but keep your good eye on both your work and the door, waiting for them to come and punish you a second time for you blatant defiance. Your work is not interrupted, even while you grind the tip on the lathe, achieving a razor sharp edge on the spearhead. Perhaps they didn’t notice or perhaps they bought the deceptive picture in your mind’s eye of using the “new tool” to force a jammed gear after having so much trouble with the last one…
14121.title: You craft the spear

141211.content:
You hear footsteps outside your door.

“I finished the last task hours ago, I hope you got a more challenging project, or at least something better to eat this time!” You call out gruffly as approach the door with the iron spear in hand. You try to consciously ignore the adrenaline coursing through your system. You hear the latch slide and then the door swings open much too fast. There are two figures in the doorway, one is a mindflayer and the other is a troll.

“BLASTED SQUID!” You shout as you realize you are both outsmarted and outmatched. You lunge forward, thrusting the spear past the troll, straight for the mindflayer’s head…

But the troll reaches out and catches your spear in mid-thrust. You are as strong as or stronger than just about every man you have ever met, but you’re not as strong as a troll. You let go of the spear and run back toward the anvil where your smithing hammer rests. If you could throw it at the mindflayer’s head, you might be able to take on the troll…

There is a flash of light from behind your eyes and you feel the force of a maul hitting the inside of your skull. The ground comes up to smack you in the face as you fall from the illithid’s mind blast. Your last thought before you lose consciousness is that you hope they don’t take your other eye…
141211.title: Running with a sharp pointy object

14122.content:
You decide the mace would be the best compromise between speed and damage. Grabbing the twisted chunk of iron and a two foot bar, you whistle nonchalantly and begin cutting a groove and notch. If this works, you might be able to crush a mindflayer’s skull before it blasts your brain. Just as long as you get the drop on it and there isn’t a group of them like the first time.

As you work, you pretend that you are crafting a bigger hammer in order to make your job easier, hoping that will fool the squiddies. Still, you can’t help but keep your good eye on both your work and the door, waiting for them to come and punish you a second time for you blatant defiance. Your work is not interrupted and you pound notched end of the bar into the groove and then hammer it closed. Perhaps they didn’t notice or perhaps they bought the deceptive picture in your mind’s eye of using the “bigger hammer” on some of the tougher tasks…
14122.title: You craft the mace

141221.content:
You hear footsteps outside your door.

“You can have your little smithing hammer back; I made a new one that’s the proper size and weight! And I hope you got food, because I’m starving!” You call out gruffly as you approach door with the smithing hammer in one hand and the new mace in the other. You try to consciously ignore the adrenaline coursing through your system. You hear the latch slide and then the door swings open much too fast. There are two figures in the doorway, one is a mindflayer and the other is a troll.

“AAAARGH” You roar as you realize that you are both outsmarted and outmatched. You desperately throw the smithing hammer right at the mindflayer’s head. The troll tries to reach out and deflect it, but misses as the hammer flies perfectly toward its target, making a little rapid whooshing sound.

The flying hammer strikes the illithid right in the forehead with a nice loud “thunk”. It staggers back, stunned from your lucky blow, as the hammer clatters to the ground.

The troll swipes at you with the back of his hand, but you duck, spin, and send your improvised mace crashing into his leg. There is a satisfying crunch and the troll stumbles on his completely shattered knee. You swing the mace back, knocking the troll’s grasping hand away from you, and then you bring it down on his head as he bends low from stumbling. Another satisfying crunch resounds as you bury the heavy twisted chuck of iron into the troll’s skull. The troll collapses the ground.

You know that trolls regenerate, but you also see that the mindflayer looks like it might be recovering. You scream another battle cry and charge forward, catching the mindflayer in the ribs just as it was about to straighten up. A second blow to the tentacled head has the desired fatal effect and it slumps down, unable to live without the bits of brain matter that are now logged in the bloody twisted chunk of iron.

There is no time to waste. You reach down and grab the smithing hammer from the floor, and then run back into the room, dropping the mace for now. A brief search yields a flat piece of scrap metal that is wide on one end and sharp on the other. You hold the sharp end on the back of the troll’s neck as it tries to get up from the ground, its bashed head already growing back like a dry sponge filling itself with water. You then hammer the back of the scrap metal like a wide chisel and, in about four or five very pissed-off blows, you sever the troll’s head from its neck. The body slumps back to the floor, twitching.

“Let’s see ya grow THAT back you son of a bitch!”

Panting for breath, but elated, you drop the metal plate, tuck the smithing hammer into your belt, and grab your mace. Just to be safe, you grab the troll’s head and toss it into the glowing sputtering hot forge, grunting with satisfaction as it bursts into flames. You leave the workshop now, ready to beat down anything else that gets in your way.

There are two directions to take in the passage outside the workshop…
141221.title: Time to crack some skulls

14123.content:
You decide that a weapon won’t do you much good if it can’t do enough damage to kill. Grabbing the twisted chunk of iron, a foot long chain, and a two foot bar; you whistle nonchalantly and begin cutting a groove. If you can manage to finish this flail, it should be quite deadly. Just as long as you get the drop on the mindflayer and there isn’t a group of them like the first time.

As you pound a pin through a hole in the handle, attaching it to the end of the chain, you pick up the pace and try to finish as fast as possible, since the nature of your little project is quite obvious. You finish the handle and grab another cotter pin to attach the other end of the chain to a hole in the twisted chunk of iron…
14123.title: You craft the flail

141231.content:
You hear footsteps outside your door.

You fumble with the cotter pin, frantically trying to line it up and pound it in place. If you can’t get the twisted chuck of iron attached to the chain, this weapon will be useless. You hear the latch slide as you start pounding on the pin. All too soon, the swings open. There are two figures in the doorway, one is a mindflayer and the other is a troll.

“AAAARGH” You roar as you realize that you are outmatched and you have run out of time. You desperately throw the smithing hammer right at the mindflayer’s head. The troll tries to reach out and deflect it, but misses as the hammer flies perfectly toward its target, making a little rapid whooshing sound.

The flying hammer strikes the illithid right in the forehead with a nice loud “thunk”. It staggers back, stunned from your lucky blow, as the hammer falls to the ground.

Troll shrieks and charges at you from the doorway. You heft the flail up, knowing that the pin is barely tapped into place, and hope that it holds. The troll closes the distance in only three bounding steps and you swing the flail.

The troll throws its arm up reflexively and catches the chain near the heavy chunk of iron, which continues with the force of your swing, snapping free of the cotor pin and grazing the back of the troll’s head as it flies across the room and clunks into the far wall. The troll grabs the parried chain with one hand and grabs you beard with the other, pulling you up into the air. You punch, kick, and scream, but it is no use. The troll swings you by your beard and bashes your against the nearby anvil, knocking you silly with blinding pain. The last thing you see is his horrible long festering teeth as he pins you to the anvil and bites into the side of your neck. The last thing you feel is intense pain, and then everything fades.

You are dead. Feel free to go back and try another path, since thankfully, this is only a story.
141231.title: Wait, I'm not finished!

choices: Help arrives in the form of an injured patient
You 'unheal' the goblin thrall that brings you food
142.content:
You have no memory of how you got to this cold, dark, dismal underground city, or how long you have been a captive of its evil inhabitants, the Illithid. You don’t even remember your own name. They call you “healer” because that’s what you do. You are the only physician to a growing population of terrified slaves and mindless thralls.

You have never had to heal an Illithid, or “mind flayer” as most slaves call them; perhaps they have their own healers. You stitch open wounds and splint broken bones and make a healing and numbing salve from the local mushrooms, but you know you were once capable of much more. You have been having dreams. The dreams seem so real and so familiar that they must be your past.

You dream of a temple, and fellow priests, and using powers of healing and light granted by the deity Pelor. You dream of adventures and battles and victories. You dream of a white staff with a fist-sized opal at one end. In your dreams, you use that staff to fight off evil monsters and to heal your fallen comrades.

But you don’t know what happened to your staff, or how to get out to the large cell that is the infirmary, or where you would go if you did get out. For now, you resign your self to continue healing those in need, being a comfort to the frightened fellow captives, and dream, because each dream seems to fill in more of the puzzle that is your shattered past.
142.title: Healer, the Human Priestess

1422.content:
You are at your wits' end. The last three patients you had, died. You can only do so much without the healing magic that you so clearly remember using. You need to get out of this horrible place, if for no other reason, then to find your staff!

Every day, a mindless goblin thrall brings you food (if you can call a pile of gristlely scraps of mystery meat suspended in rancid smelling and worse tasting gritty paste - "food"). He is armed with a short sword, but he looks much less formidable then the large powerful troll that drags patients into your infirmary on occasion.

So this time, when the goblin thrall unlatches your door and enters with the heaping plate of yuck, you make your move.

"Oh no! What happened? How did you hurt yourself?" You fein concern and approach the drooling thrall.

It looks down at itself, searching for an injury that it was unaware of. As soon as you're close enough, you grab the hilt of its short sword and yank it free of its scabbard. The goblin grabs for it too, but only manages to grab the blade as you pull, slicing his hand deeply. You can't help but be creeped out by the goblin's lack of reaction to his sliced hand. You know that he is under the control of an illithid, but you hope that the controlling master is not near enough to catch you before you can make a run for it.

The goblin thrall grabs your arm with its good hand and attempts to sink its teeth into you hand. You shove the goblin off of you and bring the sword around as hard as you can. The blade catches it in the throat. Black goblin blood sprays across the room from its severed arteries. You reel back in disgust, but you are also elated with the luck of you unskilled swing.

You dash out of the open door and into the dimly-lit passage, hoping your luck continues with your choice of direction.
1422.title: I'll give you some feedback on the cuisine

choices: You go down the left descending passage
You go up the right ascending passage
14221.content:
Trembling with adrenaline and clutching the black blood-soaked shortsword, you rush down the dimly lit passage to your left. It twists and turns. It is so dark in some places that you have to slow down feel your way along the roughly hewn wall.

Under one of the dim pale glowing spheres that sporadically light the passage, there is another juncture. You can see that the left passage slopes downward and the right passage slopes upward…
14221.title: This place is a maze

142212.content:
You go up the right passage, hoping that the slight incline means that it leads to the surface. You start to slow down, though, when you notice that the walls of this passage are covered with holes. You don’t know what the holes are, but they make the hair stand up on the back of your neck. You hesitate, trying to determine if you should run forward and try to pass them, of if you should go back and take the descending passage instead, going deeper into this abyssal maze.

Hundreds of slimy dark tentacles suddenly shoot from the holes and latch on to your arms and legs. You scream and try to slash at them with your sword, but you can’t move your arm as they are pulling it with impossible strength away from your body. You are being drawn and quartered by these horrible things and you are powerless to stop it. You cry out in pain from the tendons ripping from your every bone and you try to focus on your deity Pelor. You hope that he will be pleased with you, since you know you will see him very soon…

You have died. Feel free to go back and try another path, since thankfully, this is only a story.
142212.title: I've got a bad feeling about this...

choices: Someone is sneaking around the adjoining passage and starts pulling levers.
You carve a bone throwing knife from the food scraps and await the next feeding.
Someone lands with a loud clang on top of the metal grate over your head.
143.content:
You are a mature Halfling woman, but your slender figure and delicate features cause many to mistake you for a young human child. This fact has made your profession as a talented rogue easier in the past, but now, you believe it is the only thing keeping you alive.

You were following an unsuspecting dwarven expedition into a deep system of caverns. You know that where there are dwarves, there is treasure. The group you were following, accompanied by a rather fearsome looking minotaur, was so noisy and oblivious that it was child’s play to follow them unnoticed. When they were attacked, you thought you were far enough behind them to be out of danger, but you were wrong. An unseen presence reached out from the darkness and hit your mind like an invisible sledgehammer.

You awoke to blood-curdling screams. You watched in disgust as a mind flayer used the tentacles hanging from its squid-like face to pry open the skull of a living dwarf and suck up its bloody brain like a freshly baked crimson bread pudding. It then tossed the twitching dwarf carcass down a metal trap door. You could hear a horrible grinding noise shortly afterward. You were waiting for your turn, locked in a tiny cell like several other prisoners, each trapped in their own cell like animals in cages. You looked frantically for a means of escape, but found that the cage locks are opened by levers in the adjoining passage, so they cannot be picked with the tools you have hidden in your clothing.

Each time a mind flayer entered the room, it would devour the brain of another screaming victim. When the others ran out, you thought you were next. But an unusually long span of time passed and then more prisoners were brought in and the mind flayers began to feed off of them. A drooling, blank staring goblin even started bringing you scraps of food to eat every day.

It was then that you realized that they were waiting for you to grow up! You must escape before your captors realize that you are already an adult, otherwise… yech!
143.title: Jade, the Halfling Rogue

1432.content:
You found a thick six inch long bone in one of the horrendous meals the goblin thrall slid under your cage today. You don't know what the bone belonged to and you really don't care. What makes it interesting is the size, shape, and rigidity. You waste no time grinding it back and forth on the rough stone floor that has made you so cold and sore.

After about an hour of work, you have managed to whittle and sand the bone into a passable throwing knife. Its not heavy enough to be balanced, but if you fling it from the palm of your hand, it just might put someone's eyes out. You conceal the blade and wait for an opportunity to use it...
1432.title: Oh look, a nice long bone!

choices: You rally the other captives to use their numbers and desperation
You hide in the chute under the trapdoor
14321.content:
The opportunity presents itself barely moments after you conceal your new toy...

You hear a familiar shuffling from down the hall as a hungry mindflayer approaches the 'dining room' where you and a few others wait, like items on a buffet. The mindflayer pauses in the passage leading to the room and pulls one of the levers. A cage door pops open, causing the head of the comatose dwarf that was lying up against it to fall and hit the rock floor with a "thunk". The dwarf winces and blinks his eyes groggily, trying to look around and make sense of his surroundings. The mindflayer wastes no time walking briskly into the room and up to the dwarf's cell, grabbing the confused dwarf by the collar and dragging and lifting him to pin his head to the top of the blood-stained stone pedestal at the center of the room. The mindflayers tentacles wriggle and then attach to the dwarf's scalp, instantly slicing through skin and hair, causing the recovering dwarf to scream with pain and panic...

You fling the razor sharp bone through the air, between the bars of your cage...

"Swwhk"

The crude knife imbeds itself straight into the mindflayer's big milky-white eye. It shrieks, tentacles flailing wildly in front of its head as it lets go of the dwarf to grab at the blade. The dwarf begins punching, kicking, biting, and finally swatting at the blade. A lucky swing drives the bone the rest of the way in, all 6 inches disappearing into the mindflayers bloody eye, impaling its brain! The dwarf, still screaming in horror and bleeding profusely from the cuts in his head, shoves the illithid hard. It stumbles and falls, directly into the trapdoor by the pedestal, falling down the chute and making a satisfying crunching and grinding noise on its way down.

"Quick!" You shout urgently at the still panicking and bewildered dwarf, "Start pulling those levers in the hallway!" They'll be here soon! Let the rest of us out before they get here!"

The dwarf looks at you through the blood pouring down his face and into his beard. He wobbles and looks like he's about to pass out, but then he turns and staggers to the passage, grasping at and pulling down each lever as he reaches it...

One by one, the cage doors start popping open and then, at last, your own door swings open and you dash out toward the dwarf. He slumps down, muttering something under his blood-soaked beard and then collapses before you can reach him. You realize that he lost too much blood, so you thank him and shut his dead, staring eyes. Now you hear shuffling from down the dark passage. They're here already!
14321.title: Sock em, bite em, kick em in the shin!

143212.content:
The other captives are either comatose or too frightened to be of any help. You dash back into the room and carefully push through the spring-loaded metal trapdoor in the floor. You can see a blood-soaked metal chute leading downward at about a 70 degree angle, with a flickering light coming from below. You crawl down inside, using your hands and feet to press against the side and keep from sliding down its slippery length. As the trap door springs shut behind you, you toss the hem of your cloak up to the vanishing opening and it gets caught by the trapdoor just in time. You are now half hanging by your cloak and half pressed up against the slippery walls, trying desperately not to slide down...

You hear a commotion overhead as the mindflayers enter the room and start subduing the screaming captives. Cold panic grips you as wonder if they will sense you hear, or decide to take a meal and drop a body on top of you. Then, as your eyes adjust, you see that the flickering light at the bottom of the shaft is coming from a large set of whirling blades and it dawns on you that the bone you crafted into a knife and the 'meals' you have been eating were all from the brainless bodies that have been dropped down this chute. You vomit down the shaft, trying to keep your gagging and retching as quite as possible...

The there is the sounds of a struggle directly above you followed by a blood-curdling death scream. You realize with terror that one of the mindflayers is "eating".

You grab at the edge of the trap door and manage to pull it down with one hand and grab the lip of the chute with the other. Quickly pulling yourself up and onto the floor, you see that there are two mindflayers in the room. One is pushing a comatose captive back into a cage and the other is sucking the brains out of a poor young human man. You make a mad, but silent dash for the passage and only after you have put a hundred feet between you and the "dining room" do you take your first breath. Gasping and double checking that you are not being pursued. Presently, you find yourself at an intersecting passage.
143212.title: Hide and don't seek

choices: Do you leave alone, thinking your chances will be better without companions?
Do you try to ralley them and escape together?
1433.content:
You look up toward the fetid, grated ceiling into the darkness above and can just make out the silhouette of a slender humanoid, probably an elven female, judging by her size and shape.

"Hey!" You risk a whispered shout.

"Hey... are you okay?" The decidedly female elven voice replies.

"I'd be better if you could pull on that metal bar next to you that keeps my cage locked!"

The elf fumbles around and then finds the lever activated lock and pulls it upward, straining against the lack of leverage that the lever in the other passage would have provided. Finally, your door pops open.

"Yes!" you squeal a little too loudly. Then you bring it back down to a whisper. "Thank you!"

"Anytime!" The elf whispers. "I don't see a way through this grate, so I'm going to keep going. My name is Areal, by the way. Maybe will meet up later. If not, good luck."

"I'm Jade. I'll keep an eye out for you on my way out of this hell. Thanks again."

With that, the elf runs off across the metal grate overhead with much more stealth than her initial entrance.

Surprisingly, the entire exchange did not even cause a stir among the other survivors in the adjoining cells. Maybe they're unconscious or heavy sleepers, or maybe they have just accepted death like a free man would a bird in the air.
1433.title: It's raining elves

14331.content:
You decide to leave the captives in the other cells to their black sleep. You silently dart out of the round room ringed with cages and through passage with levers that open their locks lined down the left wall. When you turn the corner, you find yourself in a long and dark corridor that is riddled with holes. You smell a trap. You experienced rogue senses reach out before you as you creep ahead carefully searching for some pressure plate or other trigger...

You only make it ten feet into the passage when tentacles shoot out from the holes, reaching for you with their impossible numbers. Terrified, you stop to turn back, but only succeed in making their work easier. They grasp at your body and hold you splayed like a scarecrow. Whatever creatures exist as a security system, they excitedly grab you with their fetid tentacles as though it has been a long time since they had tasted meat. You begin to scream, hoping that perhaps your cellmates will hear you and come to your rescue.

They don't. They watch from the doorway in horror, not lifting a finger as the tentacles make short work of you. One by on, they prize off your limbs, sending crimson splashes reeling across the corridor and themselves. Your life ends when they pull the head from your limb-less torso, but their fun continues for hours.
14331.title: I'm better off alone

14332.content:
You dart silently to the passage at the far end of the round cage-lined room and start pulling levers. One by one, the cage doors pop open.

Four of your captives stir and jump up when they realize what is happening. Sadly, the three remaining captives lie motionless in their cages, even after you give each of them a little kick. They're either dead or unconscious from a mind flayer's mind blast. Not waiting for you or the motionless ones, the four freed captives rush ahead blindly with the promise of freedom. Catching up with them, you head down the corridor, also excited by the premise of escape.

A gentle slithering culminates into the deafening writhing of a thousand tentacles as suddenly they force their way into the corridor through holes in the walls. Terrified, you begin to sprint ahead. A dwarf in front of you lets out a yell of horror as he is seized and set upon by a dozen greedy tentacles, and an elf is brought to the floor as one wraps itself around his legs. Leaving them behind, you take the lead as your jail mates fall one-by-one, their screams following you towards what you hope is the exit.

You reach the end of the corridor with a single female survivor, the wet sounds of tentacles and a few groans of agony still audible deep into the corridor. You pray that your cellmates met quick deaths, but suspect that their suffering was long and horrific.

You leave the corridor via a door into a bare room that houses only a blank-staring goblin sitting on a chair. There are two doors. A wooden door like the one to you just entered, and a larger steel one that you suspect may lead outside.
14332.title: Up and at'em

144.content:
You look down at the subject bound below you on a flat stone slab, bound psionically by the Illithid master who gives you tasks such as this experiment you knew what was happening in his mind. He would be raging against the Illithid's compulsion but unless the Illithid lost concentration he would not be able to move his limbs. That was this Illithid's way, he did not obliterate thought as most of them did, preferring to taunt and torture the slaves. Another fact you remember for later, stored in the back of your mind while the dutiful slave sat there in the front of your mind and fooled the Illithid into thinking you were a thrall.

Instructions floated into your head “Cast the spell” and so you did, distaste hovered in the back of your head as you summoned the weave, tugging one thread loose to guide your spell you tie a glyph to the subject. It was a variant of one you have seen cast before.

As a boy the adults of your village had discovered one traveler bore a mother cyst, a few scrapings in another person of which would cause them to grow a cyst of their own, the bearer of the mother cyst will then be able to influence their thoughts, create illnesses, delirium and other ailments. Recognising your talent as a spellcaster the traveler explained the glyph to you before using it on a villager to prime them for a cyst. Panicking you tried to protect the villager and ended up casting a flare spell that set the traveler's hair alight. This distracted him long enough for the villagers to subdue him.

This glyph was similar enough that you're sure it is priming the subject for some mind affecting parasite. “It is necessary” you think, feeling that ever present power being drawn from the shadow weave somewhere deeper in the machine you are being forced to work in. “The lesser evil for the greater good.”

You turn and see thralls draging the figure along behind the Illithid. They lock the door behind them leaving you inside
144.title: Croton, Human Sorcerer and student of metamagic

145.content:
Not sold on the six original chraracters? Just add your own!

Please be sure that the character's back story is in 2nd person narrative and answers the following questions:
1. How where you captured by the Illithid?
2. Do have any or all of your memories? (Illithid often wipe your mind before making you a slave)
3. If you don't remember your name, what is your nickname?
4. Were you or are you a thrall? (Under direct puppet-like mind control)
5. Are you waiting to have your brain devoured, or have they found a use for you?
6. What is your current situation and what possibilities are there for escape?

I will make room for new characters if these slots are filled. After you add one, I will change the selection and chapter titles to reflect your new character.
145.title: Custom Characters

choices: Reveal the nature of the 'machine' (major spoiler alert)
15.content:
The Illithid city consists of a huge cavern deep underground with a network of 9’ - 12’ deep grooves carved into the base to form tunnels and chambers. Each tunnel and chamber is topped with an iron grate. The iron grates provide ventilation and security, as well as an eerie effect of hearing muffled sounds from all over. There are several access hatches in the grate that can only be opened from above, giving the illithid quick access to different parts of the city.

The exact layout of the city is not as important as where you want to lead the characters in the story.

Here are the areas of interest:

1. Mills – There are manually turned mills below the workshop, generator, lab, and kitchen. The mills are hand-turned in 4 separate sub-level rooms by slaves (one is turned by Torune, the others are tuned by ogres).

2. Workshop – Contains a lathe (powered by Torune’s mill), an electric forge, an anvil, workbenches, raw materials, a scrap heap, and various smithing and crafting tools. Argos is currently the only slave working in it. The healer’s staff, broken in 2 pieces and missing the opal headpiece, lies in the scrap heap.

3. Generator – Provides dim lighting (for the slaves that don’t have dark vision) and power to the workshop, lab, and portal chamber via large suspended cables. The generator is primarily powered by a small permanent portal to the elemental plane of air which blows a wind mill. The wind is not 100% steady or reliable, so a manually turned mill provides some back and stability.

4. Lab – Contains workbenches, precision tools, power tools, and a lathe. Whitebeard is currently the only slave working in it. Among the raw materials for the illithid projects is the opal from the healer’s staff.

5. Kitchen – A chute leads from the ceiling grate of this room into a large meat grinder, where corpses from the “Dining Room” are chopped into pieces on their way down. An orc slave separates flesh from bone and cooks the flesh for consumption by the slaves and thralls. The orc “chef” also adds chopped mushrooms, bats, beetles, rats, and lizards to complete the “meals”.

6. Dining Room – large round upper-story room made up of iron gratings for the floor, wall, and ceiling, lined with cages. In the center of the room are a bloody pedestal and a trapdoor (over a chute leading to the kitchen grinder. The passage leading to this room is lined with levers that open the cages. There are 15 cages (and 15 corresponding levers).

7. Infirmary – Contains beds and medical supplies. “Healer” is the only physician. Currently, there are no patients.

8. Servant Quarters – Four large rooms down a large hall form a barracks for slaves and thralls. Only slaves that have proven their loyalty over a long period of time are allowed to stay in the quarters (instead of simply being locked into their current work area). The slaves and thralls act as laborers, servants, and guards.

9. Master Quarters – Several rooms down 2 long parallel hallways comfortably house each illithid. The halls lead from the Servant Quarters to the Brain Pool and are always well guarded.

10. Storage – Contains a large junk heap. Semi-useful items and crude weapons can be found in it.

11. Hatchery – This chamber is where the illithid produce their larvae. It is also a sort of bioengineering laboratory where the illithid experiment with symbiotic organisms. If the solitary illithid in this room is dealt with and the room is searched, a searcher will be attacked by one of the experimental symbiants. The symbiant will attach itself to the back of the victim’s head and burrow tendrils into the brain. Fortunately, the symbiant’s will is not that strong and can be resisted. Every hour or two that the host is awake and in the illithid city, there is a chance that the host will be temporarily under the control of the Elder Brain. Torune and Arial are the most suseptable to this, while the Healer and Whitebeard are the least. The host gains psionic abilities (telekinesis, mind blast, and resist psionics).

12. Vault – Contains treasure consisting of coins, precious stones, and valuable possessions taken from captives (like the players’ gear and weapons). The door is locked psionically and can only be opened by a player with the symbiant.

13. Watcher’s Chamber – A few illithid stay here in shifts to oversee slave work throughout the city. There is an elaborate system of mirrors that allows them to visually monitor every area in the city. The dim, somewhat sporadic lighting and the lack of their full attention provides a chance that any short activity will go unnoticed. There is a psionically imbued floating disk that allows one of them to float to different parts of the city or up to the rafters. The disk is controlled psionically, so if captured, it will only hover or drift unless the rider can find a way to push/pull it in the direction they want to go (unless they have the illithid symbiant).

14. Brain Pool – Huge iron-domed central chamber contains the massive pool of goo where the Elder Brain and the new larvae live. This area is heavily guarded, though Elder Brain is capable of defending itself with powerful psionic abilities.

15. Entrance Shaft – The main tunnel leading out of the illithid city consists of huge closed iron doors and two heavily guarded gatehouses. Outside of the iron doors is a drawbridge over an underground chasm. One gatehouse controls the doors and the other controls the bridge.

16. Mushroom Farm – Slaves harvest mushrooms from the walls of a natural cavern at the edge of the city.

17. Drider Cave – This cave at the outer edge of the city is full of webs and dried carcasses. There is a chance of meeting the drider here. The drider’s spellbook can also be found.

18. Mine Entrance – A system of tunnels leads out from the edge of the city. Slaves dig for stone and metal. It is lightly guarded, but leads only to dead ends.

19. Mineral Spring – This warm bubbling pool is the water supply for the city. It leads to a network of underwater tunnels and can eventually lead out for someone capable of breathing underwater.

20. Rafters – gear boxes and suspended power cables are connected via a network of iron rails. With the gears and cables being prone to wear and tear (like slipping, jamming, or corrosion), this area needs regular maintenance. The gear boxes are tapered and lined with razor sharp ridges down the upper potions of each shaft, making them impossible to climb down. The cables and connectors are powered with a fatal electrical current 90% of the time, occasionally going “dark” for 1 to 10 seconds, when no power is coming from the generator. Sometimes there is a broken connection or a short power outage, but the drider guards this area vigilantly whenever that occurs. Arial is the current slave tasked with maintenance in the rafters.

21. Sewer – All rooms contain small disposal chutes (about a foot in diameter) that lead to the sewer. The sewer itself is a large sub-chamber, populated by one hungry otyugh. The chute from the kitchen is 4 foot in diameter. If anyone unfortunate enough to enter the sewer through the kitchen chute manages to get past the otyugh, they can climb up to an exposed natural system of caves that will eventually lead to an exit.

And finally...
15.title: Dungeon Masters only (spoiler alert)

151.content:
The Portal Chamber...

The “machine” is an intra-dimentional portal that allows the illithid to raid alternate material planes in order to capture slaves. The portal itself is a 6’ diameter round crystal lens with various powered mechanisms pointing at it. There is also an elaborate control panel to “aim” and activate the portal. It can be activated by randomly manipulating controls. If activated, the random destination is visible through the lens and can be seen before entering (the details of the destination, known only after entering it, are in parinthesis). A character can continue to manipulate the controls until they see a destination that appeals to them (unless they're being pursued).

Portal Destinations:
1. Forest (the area directly above-ground from this location)
2. Icy plane (frozen tundra inhabited by warring factions of intelligent polar bears)
3. Sand dunes (a vast desert inhabited by bandit tribes, mantis warriors, & bulettes)
4. Jungle (a dark jungle inhabited by dinosaurs, tribal guerillas, pygmies, & yuan-ti)
5. Brick building (modern day urban America, in the middle of a street)
6. Swamp (a dark swamp with giant mushrooms and strange creatures)
7. Dark hall (necropolis ruled by a lich king, a beholder, and a small remnant of the living)
8. Swirling mist (Limbo, between a githyanki monastery and slaadi spawning pools)
9. Ruins (post apocalyptic future, with human survivors, robots, and mutants)
10. Blue hall (self sustaining abandoned alien ship, ravaged by a virus and floating in space)

After entering a portal, characters will see that the potal is two-way, but that time on the other side is frozen. This means that if they are being pursued, they can spend as much time in the new location before returning and dealing with the pursuers (hopefully with some sort of weapon or help obtained from the other plane.

Also, note that some of the planes are not in the D&D setting, such as number 5. Feel free to add strange slaves or feeding victems, such as a teenage skater from California, etc. in order to give the readers a hint as to the nature of the machine.
151.title: Reveal the nature of the 'machine'

info.brief_description: Can you escape the Illithid city?  This is an epic tale in the Dungeons & Dragons setting.
info.description:
The Illithid (a.k.a. Mindflayers) capture those who stray too close to their underground lair. Some captives are slaves, the rest are feeders, their brains devoured by the terrible squid-like humanoids. The city is alive with cables and moving gears, like some giant machine. But what does it do? And can you escape?

This is a 2nd person narrative in the Dungeons & Dragons setting. No die rolls or game mechanics, only story telling.

If you wish to contribute, use the "Dungeon Masters Only" link. I will edit additions if they conflict with the info provided.

If you are just reading and want more chapters for a particular character, tell me which character and I will focus on furthering that line of the adventure.
